title: Thursday, 25th February, 2016

11:08 am
BE

Oh, sure. Why not.

PM

This is a Brexit free zone, so there's only some of his latest note i can share

But i can reveal that he's....a buyer of JGBs

11:09 am
PM

natch

PM

I was torn this week. Should I write about Brexit or about the continued turmoil that continues
to hound financial markets at a global level? It might not surprise readers that I have pretty
strong views about the UK referendum on leaving the EU, not all of which would be suitable
on these pages but I will give some quick thoughts this week and more in the run up to the
referendum. But I really want to focus on what was, in retrospect, probably the most fantastic
investment of the last decade – namely Japanese bonds. With 10y JGBs yesterday falling to
record low negative yields of minus 0.06% and Switzerland 10y having already fallen to minus
0.5, I’m now in the process completely rethinking my Ice Age investment thesis.

PM

A couple of charts

11:09 am
PM

PM

Who'd have thought?

PM

11:10 am
PM

Skipping through the views on Brexit, I will add...

PM

Let’s get back to contemplating the Ice Age and our strategic overweight 10y+ global
government bonds we have steadfastly held for almost two decades versus global
equities. We occasionally update our chart of the relative performance showing that despite
being three years too early with our strategic call, global bonds have outperformed with a lot
less volatility (see chart below). The fact that global equities caught up again with global
bonds in the middle of 2015, just as they did in late 2007 should have been a sign that things
were about to turn nasty once again for the equity market (see chart below).

PM

(see second chart above)

11:11 am
PM

I had a vision of what I might do in the months ahead. The US would lead the global economy
back into recession at some point I think sooner than most expect. This would catalyse
another leg in the secular equity valuation bear market, taking the US S&P Composite down
75% from its recent peak to around 550. I haven’t changed my view on that at all and look
forward to the opportunity of buying lots of cheap equities in the months and years ahead. But
it is our overweight long bond position that has me a bit flummoxed. I had felt that in the
forthcoming economic recession, US 10y bond yields would plunge below 1% and converge
with Japanese 10y yields at around ½%. That now seems a distant memory.

PM

Japanese 10y bond yields yesterday crashed below zero to a record low of minus 0.06%.
How low can they go? And having followed Swiss bond yields into negative territory (Swiss
10y yields currently stand at -0.5%), is this a shape of things to come for the US and Europe?
Japanese 10y bonds, as I highlighted on the front cover, are the only major global asset class
that have not seen a negative yoy return at any time since the Global Financial Crisis at the
start of 2007 (see chart below comparing Japanese 10y total return to US and German 10y).

PM

Can the plunge in JGB yields into negative territory be seen as a vote of no confidence in
Abenomics? It certainly can since it has been accompanied by a surge in the yen back
towards ¥110/$. Key economic indicators such as the PMI and corporate profits are now
sliding as the temporary benefits of a weaker yen wash out of the economy before achieving a
proper wage/price spiral that PM Abe had been targeting. I certainly had overestimated the
aggression the Bank of Japan would deploy to achieve its 2% core inflation target. The recent
move to negative policy rates was insufficiently aggressive to push the dollar below the critical
¥126/$ 30 year support level that would have set up a move to ¥145 and beyond. The
market’s appetite to tackle ¥126 was not helped by the close 5-4 vote for negative rates. But
are negative policy rates even a good idea in fighting deflation?

11:12 am
PM

he then goes on to quote Edward Chancellor of Breaking Wind about how negative rates are maybe one monetary trick that doesn't work

PM

But you'll have read plenty of Izzy and other Alphavillains on that already

PM

So just a lst par from Albert

11:12 am
PM

But as Andrew Lapthorne pointed out to me, “The Stupid is Not Impossible”. I believe that the
next recession will bring deeply negative rates, however damaging it might be to bank profits,
and I see central banks implementing restrictions for holding cash. And as Vincent Chaigneau,
SG’s head of bond strategy, pointed out to me a few days ago when the US 10y Note was
1.68%, If in one year that same note (then a 9y) trades at minus 0.32% (down 200bp) then
the T-Note will have delivered a total return of 19%. Not bad indeed!

PM

done

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 67.83, up 5.63 (+9.05%), High: 68.75, Low: 66.27, Volume: 150.20m

PM

BE

BE

Anyway ........... Best start with Lloyds I guess.

11:16 am
PM

yes, guess os

PM

BE

Bailed out, lossmaking bank doing special divis because its main shareholder is underwater again and can't liquidate its position.

11:17 am
BE

If the biggest shareholder were a Russian oligarch we'd be huffing and puffing and scandalised.

BE

But because it's UKFI, all is well. Efficient markets being efficient.

BE

Let's ignore that Lloyds Q4 missed consensus.

11:18 am
BE

And it's booked another £2.1bn PPI provision.

BE

Because apparently that £2.1bn PPI provision draws a line, of sorts.

BE

This is PPI exposure winding down.

11:19 am
BE

So let's ignore Lloyds' potential exposure to annuities misselling.

BE

And let's ignore Lloyds' potential exposure to packaged bank account misselling, the complaints about which are running well ahead of where PPI ever was.

BE

Instead, have some cash. From a lossmaking bank. Sure. Cool. Whatever.

11:20 am
BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

While Q4 PBT is -8% light vs consensus at £1.76bn on lower other income /
higher impairment , the 0.5p special dividend and PPI commentary appear to
show the normalisation process for Lloyds is almost complete and that future
underlying returns will accrue to shareholders which we think is key for the
stock performance. Lloyds indicate that the extra £2.1bn PPI provision
should be sufficient, that margin will expand to 2.70% in 2016 (+0.07%
y/y) somewhat allaying fears of a squeeze from competition / low rates.

BE

Overall slightly soft set of underlying Q4 earnings with underlying PBT of
£1.76bn, 8% below consensus. Revenues 2% light despite solid NIM print at
2.64% in Q4 (flat q/q) and steady average interest earning assets as noninterest
income was impacted by disposals and run-off as well as weather
related insurance claims (c.£60 million). Costs were in line with consensus but
impairments came in ahead of consensus at c.£230 million or 22bps.

11:21 am
BE

PPI charge of £2.1 billion for the quarter reflects time bar and Plevin
proposals and takes the total provided to £16 billion. The unutilised provision
of £3.5 billion is expected to be sufficient to cover an average of c.10,000
complaints per week with associated admin costs (vs. 8,000 complaints per
week in 2015). 4Q results also included £302 million of provisions for
packaged bank accounts and “a number of other product rectifications”.

BE

CET1 ratio 13% pro forma and TNAV 52.3p missed MSe due to higher
than expected dividends. Full year dividends totalled 2p, with 1.5p ordinary
and 0.5p special (in line with consensus but ahead of MSe) taking CET1 ratio
down to 13% pro forma for 20bps benfit from an insurance dividend relating
to 2015 to paid in 2016. RWAs £233 billion, -1% q/q. TNAV at year end was
52.3p (53.8p pre dividend) and company flagging improvement to 55.6p as at
19 February.

BE

Outlook reassuring on NIM and asset quality, though cost:income /
RORE targets pushed out: NIM guidance of 2.70% for FY16 +0.07% y/y is
ahead of consensus (2.63%) and should significantly allay market fears. Asset
quality ratio is now guided to below 20bps for FY16 (vs cons 19bps) which is
in-line. The push out of the cost: income target (now 45% only expected in
2019) could be indicative of lower than expected other operating income, so
we expect to see more explanation here on the call. Also given an underlying
RORE of 15% in 2015 investors will naturally query why the 13.5%-15% target
may not be met on a stat basis in 2017. The capital generation target is
improved to 2% annum (was 1.5-2%) indicating c.£4.5bn of capital flow
year (based on £223bn of RWAs) or c.10% of market cap which seems rather
appealing.

11:22 am
BE

(@Mouselet: while I've not interest in participating in this discussion, could you perhaps try phrasing that kind of thought in a less wildly offensive way? Thanks.)

BE

And Deutsche Bank.

BE

Overall, we expect the market to react positively to these results given the focus on the dividend and capital return story, and the upgraded NIM guidance. Importantly, we think Lloyds’s ability to pay special dividends and run at 13% CET1 level is confirmation that the more dovish tone from the BoE statement on capital in December is being implemented, which is positive for UK banks more generally. Lloyds is trading at 8.6x 2017 EPS, 1.2x TNAV for a forecast 7-10% Dividend yield 2016-2018. We retain our Buy rating.

11:24 am
BE

And Investec.

BE

Price: 62.2p | Target: Under Review | Rec: Buy
Once again we see Lloyds’ earnings recovery story as merely “deferred” rather than “cancelled”. A Q4 2015 Reported Loss of £0.5bn primarily reflects an unsurprising £2.1bn PPI top-up, while the underlying result was, we think, broadly in line with expectations. But with a proforma CET1 ratio of 13.0% Lloyds has declared an FY15 dividend of 2.25p plus a 0.5p “special”. Outlook comments should trigger consensus upgrades; 2016 NIM is guided to 2.70% (vs 2.63% in 2015). On 1.2x 2015 tNAV (52.3p) for 2017e RoTE of 12.2%. BUY.

For us, the key news is the actual dividend and the outlook for capital accretion and dividends. The 2.75p to be paid for 2015 represents a 4.4% yield. Lloyds is a ‘low/no growth’ bank, but capital accretion is now guided to 2% p.a. (previously 1.5%), giving us increased confidence in the validity of our existing 5p 2017e dividend forecast - an improbably high implied 2017e dividend yield of 8%. We expect a material upward share price correction to deal with that!
We regard the underlying performance as broadly “in line” with a better mix than anticipated. The Q4 2015 Underlying PBT of £1.8bn was 2% below our own £1.8bn forecast. Technically, this is an 8% miss against company-compiled consensus of £1.9bn, but that number looks somewhat “stale”, and can be ignored in our view.
Against our forecasts, we see Q4 2015 revenues of £4.3bn (+5% QoQ) as a £100m (2%) beat, offset by misses of £76m (3%) on costs and £67m (41%) on impairments, hence the small £43m (2%) miss in U/L PBT.
Of much greater significance for the share price outlook is, we think, the transition from capital build to capital return. Lloyds thinks its £16bn cumulative PPI provision will be sufficient, albeit we still assume a further c.£1bn charge. However, Lloyds has “corrected” its peculiar 30% medium-term tax guidance to 27%, and this enhances expected capital build. It is a ‘low/no growth’ bank but, in our view, offers a very high and clearly visible capital return story.
Buy rec reaffirmed. Detailed forecasts and 78p TP are placed under review

PM

PM

11:25 am

PM

BE

Yeah, I know. Results are better than expected, but off a low base, and Hester sounds .......

BE

.......... well, like Hester.

11:26 am
PM

How can the market be so surprised by something like RSA

BE

I guess there's several small pieces of good news that individually are fair enough to under-forecast, but together make up a significant positive.

BE

First, underwriting beats.

11:27 am
BE

Second, cost savings look to be ahead of plan.

BE

Third, capital is better than expected.

BE

It's rare, I guess, to get three demonstrable positives at once.

11:29 am
BE

Here's Barclays to summarise.

BE

RSA reported a strong set of numbers beating company collected consensus underlying EPS by 20% driven by a stronger combined ratio (20bps better for full year vs ccc and 1.2ppts better vs Barc), which is largely attributable to stronger attritional loss ratio (80bps better vs Barclays). Regionally, both the UK and Canada beat our estimates based on underlying underwriting performance.

Restructuring charges hit bottom line - The company missed on bottom line as it accelerates its ‘cost to save’ levels, taking £183m of restructuring charges in 2015 as well as £26m in relation to Solvency 2, which should go to zero by 2017. The company continues to guide to a ratio of 1.5x for costs taken to achieve cost savings.

Solvency 2 towards top end of target - The new Solvency 2 ratio is at the top end of the company’s target based on a pro-forma basis for the sale of Latin America (155% vs 143% reported at year end, new target of 130%-160%).

Outlook towards top end of guidance - Crucially on the outlook, the company has increased its expense savings to a gross level of £350m from ‘more than £250m’ previously, and guided towards the top end of its 12%-15% ROTE target. The company reports achieving £180m gross cost savings by end 2015 which translates to £157m in net terms, and expects to achieve £250m by end 2016 a year early.

Investment income guidance less impacted than we thought – investment income guidance has been reduced to £330m from £375m, in 2016 (Barc £345m) and then £315m in 2017 and 2018 (Barc £311m and £282m), which is better than we anticipated. Excluding the LatAm sale (£45m), the decline represents only a £10m reduction from prior guidance. The company uses the forward curves in its guidance, but also indicates only a £10m-£12m reduction in investment income if yield levels remain at spot levels.

The pension triennial review has resulted in no change to additional payments to the fund (£65m) p.a., and with significant derisking already undertaken and more to come. We note, though, that Solvency 2 captures the IAS 19 pension value now, not the funding basis, so this is less relevant than before.

The stock is trading on 1.45x trailing TBV and is at 2.7% trailing dividend yield, with a trailing underlying 9.7% ROTE.

BE

Remind me what price the Zurich abandoned bid was here? 550p, wasn't it?

11:30 am
PM

i can remember

PM

But was in that range

BE

It was. Remember he kerfuffle when we reported a 550p bid, there followed six weeks of press briefings by feltcollaredsource about realistic prices to expect, generating literally thousands of column inches ..... then after all that Zurich bid 550p.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome

BE

Anyway, that's RSA. Lots more to cover so let's move on.

undefined
11:33 am
BE

So, in amongst the meeting of the Ukip annual think-tank going on on the right, we have a few stocks mentioned ......

BE

Such as Capita.

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 1,004, down 68 (-6.34%), High: 1,122, Low: 993.00, Volume: 2.74m
11:33 am
BE

Results are a bit of a mess.

BE

At the core, it's okay. Organic growth in line with expectations.

BE

Exceptionals are considerable, however, and net debt has deteriorated considerably.

11:35 am
PM

Had a slow start to the year tho i think

BE

Yeah, that too. The most important thing, though, is that the numbers look better than they are because £161m of revenues and £1.2m of losses have been moved into discontinued column.

BE

ROIC is weaker.

11:36 am
BE

So while management repeat the 2016 guidance, it's basically for a differently shaped Capita than the guidance was previously for.

BE

There's a lot of moving parts here, which Cazenove can sum up better than me.

BE

Capita’s FY15 results see a reshaping of the business. Capita has exited a number of businesses (revs of £163m
and trading loss of £1.2m), and taken an impairment of £105m. The result sees margin guidance for the
continuing group increased to 13-14%, from 12.5-13.5% previously, and ROCE is now 15% on a continuing
basis. The FY15 financials were broadly in line with consensus. FY15 PBTA is £585.5m, 0.1% ahead of
company provided consensus, and 0.2% ahead of JPMe, EPS was 70.73p, 0.4% below consensus. Organic
growth was 4.3% compared to consensus of 3.8%. The bid pipeline stands at £4.7bn, an 8% decrease from the
£5.1bn reported in December, in line with our estimates. Net debt was disappointing at £1,839m, £182m higher
than JPMe. Capita’s ROCE continued to decline with FY15 ROCE at 14.3%, compared to 14.5% in 1H15. The
company now expects organic growth in 2016 of at least 4%, compared to consensus of 5.0%

11:37 am
BE

 FY16 guidance for at least 4% organic growth. Consensus organic growth for 2016 is 5.0%, and JPMe is
4.2% on Capita’s definition and 3.8% excluding the FERA contract. Consensus expects total revenue growth
in FY16 of 6.8% and JPMe at 6.7%.
 FY15 revenue growth of 10.5%, with organic growth of 4.3%. Organic growth is 50bps ahead of
consensus and 60bps ahead of JPMe. We estimate that Capta’s organic growth includes 100bps which we treat
as acquisition growth, and as such we see actual organic growth as c. 3.3%, compared to JPMe of 2.7%. Total
revenue was £4,837m on a reported basis, 0.2% ahead of consensus.
 EBITA was £639m, 0.1% ahead JPMe. EBITA margin of 13.2% on a reported basis and 13.7% after
removing the disposed and held for sale businesses. This compares to FY14 EBITA margin of 13.2%, (or
13.5% adjusting for those businesses now excluded). PBTA was £585.5m, 0.1% above consensus and 0.2%
above JPMe. EPS was 70.73p, 0.4% below consensus and 0.3% ahead JPMe.
 Pipeline decreases 8% to £4.7bn. The pipeline is 89% new business and has an average duration of 6 years.
Capita’s bid pipeline was £5.1bn at its December trading statement, of which 98% was new business and
decisions were due in 12 months. It had been £5.4bn in July at the 1H15 results. For our forecasts we had used
a pipeline of £4.7bn, though we have assumed a slightly longer average duration. The pipeline has recently
seen the removal of the UKAR contract (won by HML).
 Contract sales so far in 2016 are £251m.

BE

 £402m spent on acquisition in 2015, on 17 companies. At Capita’s IMS in December it had spent £375m on
16 companies. In 2014 Capita spent £310m, acquiring 17 businesses.
 Return on capital declines to 14.3%. This compares to ROCE in in 1H15 of 14.5%, FY14 of 14.8% and
1H14 of 15.4%. We had forecast ROCE of 14.0%, and for FY16 expected further declines to 13.5%.
However, after adjusting for today’s announced business disposals and held for sale the ROCE was 15% in
2015.
 ND/EBITDA of 2.5x, compared to JPMe of 2.5x. This compares to 2.4x at 1H15, and 2.1x at FY14. This is
within Capita’s target net/debt EBITDA range is 2.0-2.5x. Net debt was £1,839m, £182m higher than JPMe.
 JPM remains Neutral. We believe it will prove challenging for Capita to significantly accelerate organic
growth in 2016. Moreover, this may have a negative impact on ROCE in 2016. However, we see opportunities
for Capita on the medium term, and believe that c. 4.5% organic growth coming years should be enough to
sustain its rating. Capita is on a 2016 JPMe PER of 14.5x, and EV/EBITA of 13.2x.

BE

Sorry about the messy formatting. I'm sure anyone interested can make sense of it.

11:38 am
BE

Jefferies also highlights the lack of contract news ...........

BE

No new contracts announced but “at least 4%” LFL growth reiterated. In our
December 2015 note, we listed several bids scheduled for decisions in early 2016 including:
a German opportunity with £20-30m annual revenue (which could be 2-3x larger if
full outsourcing option is taken); an unspecified European opportunity (with £20-30m
annual revenue); an undisclosed UK CRM contract. None of these have been announced
today although we understand that two decisions are imminent (in our preview note, we
suspected a decision regarding a customer management contract with Telefónica could be
edging closer).

BE

Less reliance on new contract wins. Management have reiterated their guidance for “at
least 4%” LFL growth in FY16E. Contributory factors include: potential Q1 contract awards
start rapidly; Life and Pensions contracts won’t be a headwind as guaranteed price step
downs ceased in mid-2015; 40% of revenue isn’t driven by converting the bid pipeline into
new contract wins but rather by cross-selling services to existing customers (particularly in
the Asset Services division).
Bid pipeline decreases from £5.1bn to £4.7bn. The bid pipeline declined from £5.4bn
in July to £5.1bn in December, partly because a life & pensions opportunity, previously
capped at £1bn, had shrunk in scope. Since then, the pipeline has declined to £4.7bn but
average contract duration has fallen to 6 years (previously 8 years) so the annual revenue
opportunity is more stable. In our view, Capita’s bid pipeline could reach a record £6bn
over the next 1-2 years, driven by the DACH region and a revival in UK Central Government
activity, and consequently, group LFL growth will accelerate.
Our 1400p price target continues to apply an 18x PE multiple (in the middle of the
12-27x through the cycle range) to FY16E EPS. Risks include political changes, delayed bid
timetables and mobilisation.

11:39 am
BE

That's Kean Marden, who's a buyer.

BE

On the opposite side of things, we have Serco rallying 17% because it didn't miss consensus.

Serco Group PLC (SRP:LSE): Last: 94.50, up 12.8 (+15.67%), High: 97.50, Low: 85.35, Volume: 4.45m
11:40 am
BE

Results as expected, guidance unchanged, shares up 17%.

PM

extraordinary

BE

And much like Capita, the numbers are a mess.

11:41 am
BE

The difference, I guess, is that Serco's numbers have been a mess for a few years.

BE

Whereas messy numbers from Capita are more of a sign of things to come than a symptom of things already past.

BE

Deutsche Bank incoming.

11:42 am
BE

Serco published FY 15 results, following the trading update on 7 December. Revenue was £3,515m vs. company guidance of ~£3.5bn. The revenue base excluding the private BPO division was £3,177m. The organic decline was -10%, driven by loss of volume on the Australian Immigration Services contract, termination of contracts including DLR and the NPL.
Trading profit was £96m on an underlying basis compared with guidance of £95m as stated in the trading update and £113.2m in FY 2014. The implied underlying margin was 2.7% (FY 14: 2.9%). The headline figure of £137.6m includes a £20.9m net benefit of OCP/provision adjustments and £11.7m from excluding the D&A of assets held for sale, and £9.0m due to the early termination of work for Thurrock Council. EPS were 3.44p, down 27% on 2014.
FCF in FY 2015 was an outflow of £16m (FY 2014: inflow of £61.8m). Net debt stood at £78m (0.5x EBITDA ex BPO disposal) better than previous guidance for c.£100m. Serco estimate that closing net debt at the end of 2016E could be around £200m, equivalent to 2x EBITDA. Previous guidance was £200-250m
Onerous Contract Provisions stood at £300m at end-December 2015 from £447m at December 2014. Additional charges have been made in respect of future forecast losses of £91.8m, including revisions to existing contracts of £53.1m and new provisions of £38.7m (£34.0m for the Lincolnshire contract). In 2015, releases to the income statement from OCPs were £91.6m, including the £62.7m release on the Royal Australian Navy contract.
The bid pipeline stood at £6.5bn (H1 2015: £5bn). While this is a large percentage improvement, the pipeline was £12bn at the end of 2013. Serco state that there are around 20-30 opportunities, with the annual contract value averaging around £30m and a typical length of contract 5-10 years.
Guidance for 2016 has not changed, still for revenue of £2.8bn and underlying trading profit of £50m. The guidance for 2016E includes around £100m of incremental revenue from already secured or potential new business. For 2017E, the comment is “conditions remain uncertain and we do not expect anything more than limited financial progress.”

BE

The stock trades on 17x EV/EBITA. It is difficult to value Serco using earnings metrics given the profit figures will be volatile due individual contracts and in our view a long-term DCF is the best methodology. The statement shows improvement (importantly on the pipeline) however with new OCPs and limited growth in 2017E, we reiterate our cautious view. Hold.

BE

(@urgeview: auction book volume on Coats on my screen is literally zero.)

11:43 am
undefined
PM

We can mention BT

PM

ut we havent much to add

11:44 am
PM

But

PM

It's as expected

PM

And all the headlines are aggressive

11:44 am
PM

And the sell side is soft

PM

Cos it's as expected

PM

Some Redburn

11:45 am
PM

We have now read (almost!) all of the 108 pages published this morning by Ofcom. In line with our expectations last weekend, Openreach is seeing more regulation and the threat of separation held in reserve, but no separation today. This is leading to a little “relief” in the BT shares today.

PM

However the document contains many pro-competitive proposals. If we were to score the document between 0 and 10, where 10 is the most aggressive, this is a 7 or 8. Overall Ofcom is sticking with providing incentives for investment, so investors should not expect major changes in regulated prices, even though Ofcom clearly hints that it will regulate GEA (the wholesale version of BT Infinity) in 2017. However Openreach will have more costs on services standards and automatic compensation payments, it will have to spend to open up its ducts, it may have to invest more to prevent others overbuilding… So Openreach opFCF is justifiably going to go down – by how much we do not yet know. There are enough sticks here to make Ofcom’s statement that it is open to “voluntary proposals” on separation from BT rather meaningful. Separation is usually voluntary in the end (British Gas, New Zealand, Czech Republic)…

Full separation and a national programme of upgrade might have been a cleaner structure, but given the constraints Ofcom operates under (political with UK govt and EC, views from independent fibre builders) this is a good starting point.

PM

Just looking at what will happen LATER THIS YEAR:

PM

Service standards will cost money. Openreach will have tougher minimum service standards. If they don’t repair a line on time (~25% of the time) consumers will receive an AUTOMATIC compensation payment

· Openreach ducts opened up. Openreach will have to put its duct network online “relatively quickly”. The EU Civil Infrastructure Directive transposed into UK law in summer 2016 gives automatic rights to access key infrastructure to competitors. Openreach HAS TO OFFER THE DUCTS to others on an equal basis whenever it builds anything….

· Price regulation of fibre is coming. Page 42-44 is a fascinating read. Ofcom says that it will protect a “fair bet” investment but a “fair bet” investment involves a big upfront commitment and lots of civil work – not an incremental electronic upgrade. Ofcom does say however it will “err on the side of caution” to keep encouraging investment but we are coming to the end of the “fair bet”…

· Openreach separation. On page 70 Ofcom says there are 8 options for Openreach. The current structure is already at number 5; number 8 is full separation; number 7 – full legal separation is what Ofcom proposes. This means separate board, separate capex plan, separate R&D. It will discuss these proposals with the European Commission (not entirely sure why…).

· Full separation is held in reserve. One of the reasons Ofcom is not proposing it now is that they may want to change the perimeter and make a new “sub Openreach” of just ducts and poles for others to use…

· Ofcom is open to “voluntary proposals” from BT…

· Consumer protection. BT and others will have to show a single price over the contract period – not a confusing mish mash of rising line rental with “discounted” broadband. Ofcom will complete its review of broadband and payTV switching.

· Ofcom will deregulate landline telephony but protect those who depend on a phone line without broadband. This is important because BT has raised line rental and call charges every year for 8 years on basic customers.

· Universal Broadband Service. Will bring forward recommendations together with government on a minimum 10Mbps Universal Service Obligation, rising over time.

BE

Playtech reported a strong FY15 performance, comfortably ahead of market
expectations; and as expected, it signalled it is in a number of acquisition discussions,
but will consider cash returns if these do not deliver.
Revenues grew by 38% to €630.1m (CG €616.5m), representing impressive 16%
underlying LfL growth. Ebitda came in at €251.9m (vs CG €245.1m/consensus
€247.0m), with a stable underlying margin. EPS came in at 61.5c, ahead of our 60.2c.
The dividend was increased by 8% to 28.5c (a positive signal on growth). And it finished
the year with €657.9m of net cash (CG €674m).
Casino remained the key growth driver, up by 26%, as it benefited from new/recent
license wins - Ladbrokes, GalaCoral, Skybet etc. Services grew by 17% on the back of
white label/structured agreements, including Trinity Mirror and Caliente. Sports grew
22% from a low base, but will decline in FY16F with the loss of some mobile (front
end) contracts (William Hill etc). Land-based grew 79%, boosted by Aristocrat Lotteries
acquisition and Mecca Bingo roll-out. Markets.com saw continued growth, but was
impacted by lower market volatility in H2.

11:53 am
BE

Trading remains extremely strong, with growth of 12% in the first 53 days of Q1 (or
+18% constant currency) for the Gaming business (which is 89% of FY16F projected
profits). The pipeline looks excellent, with the Sun contract kicking in in Q4, and new
wins including Marca (Spain's biggest newspaper, with a 2.5m readership). Markets.com
started Q1 well, given market volatility. But management is adjusting the business model
- investing in regulatory infrastructure (onboarding etc) and also in its B2B platform,
which will impact short-term profits, but underpin stronger medium-term growth.
Given the extent of underlying momentum in Gaming (despite FX headwinds from the
weaker £), we leave our profit forecasts unchanged, with FY16 Ebitda of €290.4m and
EPS of 68.8c. Details of our forecasts are on pages 3 and 4.
In addition, management stated that it is in "active discussions on a number of potential
[Gaming] acquisitions" and if these do not crystallise it will consider cash returns "to
maintain an efficient balance sheet". Add in "available for sale investments" and PTEC
has €895m of available funding including "available for sale investments"; with debt,
it could push this to over €1.7bn. Given an excellent management track record on
shareholder returns from deals, we see this as a significant potential positive catalyst,
given opportunities such as Openbet.

BE

Playtech shares are on a FY17F PER of 13.4x (or 10.5x if we strip out cash) and an EV/
Ebitda of 9.3x, against a peer group average of 16.6x or EV/Ebitda 11.1x. We think this
looks too cheap for a technology leader in a structural growth market. Our 1000p TP is
unchanged and represents a 12.0x 2017F EV/Ebitda and 14.0x cash adjusted PER. BUY.

11:55 am
BE

Revenue from Markets Limited (acquired in May 2015) came in at €60m. In 2015
CFD actives and first time depositors were both +25% yoy. The margin postacquisition
was 26% (we would have expected a margin closer to 40%). The group
is making changes to the business model (enhanced compliance, increased
marketing) which will lead to a lower margin than previously anticipated in FY16.

BE

Average daily revenue for the first 53 days of 2016 is +12% (18% cc) in core
gaming (we forecast +11% in Q1 and FY16). Markets Limited has seen a strong
start to 2016 driven by strong volatility in markets (we forecast +14% in 2016).
The group had €605m net cash (post deferred consideration) and gross cash of
€858m. It states it is in active discussions on a number of potential acquisitions in
gaming. In absence of suitable deals consideration will be given to a cash return.

BE

Overall, a slightly mixed set of results from Playtech. The core gaming business is
performing slightly better on the revenue line than expected and encouragingly,
EBITDA margins are going in the right direction. However, the financials business
is underperforming what we would have expected and will not reach the margin we
previously expected (c40%) in FY16 due to investment in the business. Given it is
so soon after it was acquired this may be badly received by the market. In terms
of our forecasts we are currently at EBITDA €296m for FY16, which compares to
consensus of c€290m. We are likely to leave this unchanged at this stage, with
Core Gaming offsetting the financials lower than expected outcome. We retain our
BUY recommendation as the valuation is not overly stretched and the group has
significant capital to deploy on value enhancing acquisitions

Scottish word of the week

11:56 am
PM

The basic ingredients of a stramash, include noise and confusion, often involving a group of people in situations where there is anger, sometimes violence and often alcohol.

Stramash is most likely to be used to describe a fight of some sort: “That was some stramash outside the pub last night!”

Stramash, like many Scottish slang words is often used in the north of England and has even extended its range of influence to become a prevalent word in the commentating of football, hardly surprising given that the ingredients necessary for a stramash are often present on the pitch.

PM

Here's Alex Kram of UBS

PM

DB1/LSE confirm discussions; could ICE join the party?
Following the announcement of a potential DB1/LSE combination (which the companies have confirmed they are discussing), many investors have wondered about potential disruption from other exchange organizations. While ICE is currently digesting several other deals, many (including The Times – see here – and others, see here) have looked at ICE as a potential interloper in the space. Having published a merger model of a potential ICE/LSE combination last year, we are now providing an updated view of that potential combination.

Our updated merger model shows 3.0% accretion to ICE earnings
Our updated model suggests that a combination between ICE and LSE could drive 3.0% accretion to ICE's earnings in 2016. In our forecast, we assume a 30% premium to LSE's current share price and a 4% cost of debt. Using 30% debt to finance a potential acquisition would only drive leverage to ~3x EBITDA, which could be manageable with the prospect of quick deleveraging. We are also assuming that ICE could eliminate about 30% of LSE's cost base (~$300mm).

PM

Strategic rationale still makes sense
Following meetings with ICE management in mid-2015, we published thoughts regarding the strategic rationale behind an ICE/LSE combination (June 6, 2015 note: https://neo.ubs.com/shared/d1AtrcIdbP3J; with some follow up in our July 7, 2015 meeting takeaway note: https://neo.ubs.com/shared/d1zpRRc6NgI), and we continue to believe that LSE has complementary assets to ICE's business. Despite ICE not being too far removed from the $5bn+ purchase of IDC, given the potential shift in the competitive dynamics in Europe that would result from a DB1/LSE merger, we believe it is possible that ICE considers some combination.

12:00 pm
PM

( alewis2005 -- we are being tight lipped on Wirecard for the moment. May your own mind up on that 100 page report. Why?....reasons.)

BE

 Iron ore: Strong volumes and further cost reductions, but higher adjusted
expenses drove a 12% EBITDA miss. Vale continued to deliver impressive cost
reductions, helped by a weaker BRL, with C1 cash cost declining by 6.3% QoQ to
$11.9/t (vs. $12.7/t) and landed cost (CFR China $/dmt) reached $32/t vs. $34.1/t,
helped by a $2.3/t reduction in freight costs, which will be completely unhedged
from 1Q16 onwards. Together with record iron ore volumes (incl. pellets) of 91.7Mt
(+1.3% vs. JPMe), it helped partially offset the 20% decline in realized prices.
However, the driver of the 12% EBITDA miss for ferrous segment was higher than
expected adjusted expense and weaker than expected other ferrous EBITDA.

BE

 Base Metals: Weak results in spite of solid production. Base metals reported
weak results with EBITDA of $111M down from $193M in 3Q. The number was of
course impacted by lower commodity prices and one-off charges related to
inventory write-offs of $31M. Volumes partially compensated prices (+$108M in
nickel and +$54M in copper sequentially). Costs reduced by $45M QoQ on higher
fixed cost dilution at Sudbury. When we look at each operation individually, North
Atlantic assets delivered EBITDA of $187M, up QoQ due to higher volumes and
cost dilutions, but still below 4Q14 $435M mostly on lower prices. VNC recorded
negative EBITDA of -$107M. Pre-operating expenses were $89M, $8M lower QoQ.
 Coal and Fertilizers: both saw lower EBITDA in the quarter. Coal performance
had a slight deterioration QoQ on prices and costs. EBITDA was negative $149M.
On a positive side, Moatize II and Nacala Corridor reached 99% and 97% physical
progress respectively. Fertilizers performance deteriorated in the quarter in line with
typical seasonality of the business. EBITDA was $117M in the quarter.
 Notables. (a) VNC shareholder Sumic (Sumitomo +Mitsui) decided to exercise a put
against Vale as production targets were not met, leading Vale to acquire Sumic's
stake in VNC for $135M plus owing a $218M debt funding provided by Sumic, due
March 2017. Vale will now hold 95% of VNC (5% owned by the local government).
(b) Vale reached agreements to increase the upper limit of gross debt to adjusted
EBITDA to 5.5x (from 4.5x) until end of 16.
 Negative FCF in the quarter takes net debt higher, but marginally better than
JPMe. Vale had a FCF (before dividends) of -$423M (JPM calculation), better than
JPMe -$1.2B as the company delivered a solid ~$800M in working capital
improvement. Together with $500M dividends paid in the quarter, net debt increased
by 4% to $25.2B (but 2% lower vs. JPMe $25.8B), taking ND/EBITDA to 3.6x, vs.
3.1x in 3Q.
